awd_titl_txt: Enhancing the Performance of High Performance Liquid Chromatography and Mass Spectrometry Using Nanofibers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement & Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation. Professor Susan Olesik of the Ohio State University is developing analysis methods with the ability to detect compounds at low concentration levels with improved analysis time compared to current capabilities. Increasing challenges in this country such as the need to monitor low levels of pollutants in natural waters and the need for fast clinical and forensic analyses may be impacted by this work. The broader impacts of this work include the potential societal benefits from the discoveries of the carbon based stationary phases as well as, middle school student and teacher engagement in active science projects developed from this research.

This project focuses on liquid chromatography-mass spectrometric methods with increased kinetic performance, improved sensitivity, and unique selectivity. There are four project goals. First, a carbon based open tubular liquid chromatographic methods is being developed. Second, a carbon based packed liquid chromatographic column is being studied and developed. Third, the mechanism of nanofiber-based surface assisted laser desorption ionization are studied. Fourth, nanofiber based planar chromatography that is compatible with middle school studies are developed and added to a new active-learning, science outreach program for local middle schools.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Characterization methods with enhanced sensitivity are important in fields such as environmental pollutant analysis, clinical studies, medical diagnostics, and drug discovery. The significant scientific discoveries garnered during this work included the following insights.  Using nanofibers with approximate diameters of 300 nanometers (which is approximately 250 times smaller than the diameter of human hair) and lengths of 2-3 centimeters, a method to increase the sensitivity of detection of small molecules, such as small pharmaceutical compounds, was identified and evaluated.   This method required adding small nanoparticles (2-10 nm) that absorb ultraviolet light (UV) to the interior the larger nanofibers.  Molecules of interest (pharmaceutical compounds) were spotted onto these nanofibers. Plates of these nanofibers were placed into a device that includes a laser that emits UV light which causes desorption of the small molecules for analysis into a analyzer that is capable of determining the mass of single molecules.   The nanofiber conditions that provided the highest sensitivity for analysis, also transferred minimal energy to the measured molecules.  This is important because the molecules do not fragment into component fragments under these conditions.

Two new methods for extracting compounds from aqueous solutions using nanoscale media were developed.  The first involved the development of well-defined 50-75 nm diameter elemental carbon particles. The use of this new media was illustrated for the removal of trace amounts of herbicides from water solutions. Another method using nanofibrous material was developed that provides enhanced removal of malodorous compounds from simulated complex mixtures.

The discoveries described above are anticipated to not only improve chemical analyses, but the application of this technology is expected to impact other areas of society as well.  For example, the removal of malodorous compounds from food stuffs.

 


Last Modified: 01/01/2022
Modified by: Susan V Olesik

The significant scientific discoveries garnered during this work included the following insights.  Using nanofibers with approximate diameters of 300 nanometers (which is approximately 250 times smaller than the diameter of human hair) and lengths of 2-3 centimeters, a method to increase the sensitivity of detection of small molecules, such as small pharmaceutical compounds, was identified and evaluated.   This method required adding small nanoparticles (2-10 nm) that absorb ultraviolet light (UV) to the interior the larger nanofibers.  Molecules of interest (pharmaceutical compounds) were spotted onto these nanofibers. Plates of these nanofibers were placed into a device that includes a laser that emits UV light which causes desorption of the small molecules for analysis into a analyzer that is capable of determining the mass of single molecules.   The nanofiber conditions that provided the highest sensitivity for analysis, also transferred minimal energy to the measured molecules.  This is important because the molecules do not fragment into component fragments under these conditions.

Two new methods for extracting compounds from aqueous solutions using nanoscale media were developed.  The first involved the development of well-defined 50-75 nm diameter elemental carbon particles. The use of this new media was illustrated for the removal of trace amounts of herbicides from water solutions. Another method using nanofibrous material was developed that provides enhanced removal of malodorous compounds from simulated complex mixtures.

The discoveries described above are anticipated to not only improve chemical analyses, but the application of this technology is expected to impact other areas of society as well.  For example, the removal of malodorous compounds from food stuffs.
